clinical_study.brief_title: Use Of Virtual Reality For Pain Control in Dermatological Bedside Procedures
clinical_study.official_title: Use Of Virtual Reality For Pain Control in Dermatological Bedside Procedures

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to explore the impact of virtual reality (VR) on pain perception during out-patient procedures such as wart removal, wound debridement, and lidocaine injections.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in average pain as assessed by the visual analog scale (VAS)
primary_outcome.description: VAS has a scoring range from 0 to 10 with 0 being no pain and 10 being the worst possible pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in maximum pain level as assessed by VAS
primary_outcome.description: VAS has a scoring range from 0 to 10 with 0 being no pain and 10 being the worst possible pain.

secondary_outcome.description: Heart rate will be assessed in beats per minute.
Oxygen saturation will be assessed as a percentage.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of intervention related adverse events
secondary_outcome.description: Intervention related adverse events will be assessed per treating physician discretion.

arm_group.description: This group will receive the virtual reality intervention during out-patient bedside procedures.

intervention.description: The VR system will provide a 3D environment that provides distracting stimulus. Participant will put on the Oculus Go VR system headset 1-2 minutes prior to out-patient bedside procedure up to the completion of procedure which takes typically 3-5 minutes.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients 13 years and older.
- Patient (or health care proxy when applicable) must sign an ICF.
- Patient requiring any painful dermatological bedside procedure including: wound debridement, injections and liquid nitrogen application.
- Patients willing to participate and parents able to consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects with a diagnosis of vertigo, inner ear diseases or seizures are excluded due to the uncertainty of performance under VR conditions.
- Subjects requiring procedures on the head are also excluded to the interference of the VR headset.
